subject: Relationships
subcategory: Famous Love Stories That Changed History
title: Simone de Beauvoir and Jean-Paul Sartre
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Simone de Beauvoir and Jean-Paul Sartre.

hook.text: They never married, never lived together, and had other lovers. Yet their 51-year partnership defined modern philosophy.

buildup.text: Beauvoir and Sartre met in 1929 and created a 'pact' â€” committed to each other while rejecting monogamy.

discovery.text: Their partnership produced existentialism and feminist theory. Beauvoir's 'The Second Sex' changed the world forever.

twist.text: Critics called their arrangement exploitative. Beauvoir later admitted some of their 'openness' caused real pain.

climax.text: They proved love doesn't need traditional forms. But they also proved that reinventing love has real costs.

punchline.text: Beauvoir and Sartre reinvented love for 51 years. It was brilliant and painful.

quiz.question: How long did Beauvoir and Sartre's partnership last?
